This weekend I went Fishing with my grandson at Candlewood Lake in Connecticut and he surprised me with a question I never thought he would ask.

‚ÄúGrandpa John... Do you have Life Insurance?‚Äù

I was taken back for a moment, because what kind of 7 year old would ask such a bold question?

Rather than answering, I simply asked him what made him think to ask me that.

He put his head down for a moment before looking at me with one eye squinted and said...

‚ÄúI heard my mom and dad talking about you and they‚Äôre scared that if something happened to you we wouldn‚Äôt have the money to pay the funeral man‚Äù

I could see he was worried. I told him that everything would be fine and there was nothing to worry about.

The truth is, I didn‚Äôt have anything in place to protect them if something were to happen to me and they don‚Äôt have $10,000 lying around to cover a sudden funeral cost, either.

That was my responsibility. One I hadn‚Äôt owned up to yet.

I returned from our trip the next morning and called my friend who's a Licensed Field Underwriter. I almost paid for another insurance and then he told me that Connecticut Residents ages 50-85 years old qualify for a NEW State Regulated Burial Program that is designed to pay for our Final Expenses up to $25,000 Tax Free.

It was really simple. They approved me almost instantly and they didn‚Äôt even mind that I have some prior health conditions.

There was no Blood Work Required.

No Physical Exam, No Doctors Appointments or invasive requirements.

They provided Day One Coverage, even covered my brother who‚Äôs a diabetic that has been turned down for previous coverage.

Thanks to this program, I was able to tell my grandson and my family that everything will be fine when something happens to me.

********************************************************************
 
Alamo-disrespecting George P. Bush may kill family‚Äôs political dynasty
By Isabel Vincent
March 4, 2022 7:40am
NEW YORK POST 
 
At first glance, George Prescott Bush seems the ideal political candidate in a state where his family has been a powerful dynasty for decades.

The telegenic Texas lawyer is a grandson of 41st US President George H.W. Bush and the nephew of George W. Bush, the 43rd. He is the eldest son of two-term Florida Gov. Jeb Bush and the great-grandson of US Sen. Prescott Bush of Connecticut. The war veteran and father of two, married to blond lawyer Amanda Williams Bush, is also Mexican American on his mother‚Äôs side, and speaks fluent Spanish.

But that might not be enough, according to critics who accuse him of being the black sheep of the family and disrespecting the Alamo, Texas‚Äô most treasured symbol, by bringing in modern-minded out-of-staters for its restoration.

On Tuesday, Bush, 45, and incumbent Ken Paxton beat two other Republican candidates vying to be the party‚Äôs pick in the attorney general‚Äôs race.

Now, a critical May runoff will determine whether the fourth-generation scion will be able to shore up the family‚Äôs political legacy in the Lone Star State, analysts say. 

But that‚Äôs another problem: ‚ÄúThe Bush name is not popular in Texas anymore,‚Äù Luke Twombly, a Dallas-based political consultant and former communications director of the Texas Republican Party, told The Post.

Paxton, the Texas attorney general since 2015, has been indicted on securities fraud charges and accused of bribery and misuse of office in a civil whistleblower lawsuit, but still has the support of the state‚Äôs conservatives. He also has the endorsement of former President Donald Trump ‚Äî a situation Bush hopes to reverse by invoking Trump in his campaign ads, which don‚Äôt mention the titans in his own family.

‚ÄúUnder the leadership of President Trump, our country was strong and vibrant again,‚Äù says Bush in a campaign video. At another point in the ad, he notes, ‚ÄúLike President Trump, I will not sit idly by while our freedoms are under attack, because Texas must lead the way in fighting this radical agenda.‚Äù 

If Bush is trying to capitalize on his devotion to Trump, his opponents hope to end the Bush family‚Äôs political dominance in Texas, which began after George H.W. moved with his wife, Barbara, from Connecticut to the Lone Star State in 1948 to work in the oil business.

‚ÄúIf conservatives unite ‚Ä¶ we can end the Bush dynasty,‚Äù Paxton told a Lubbock radio station Wednesday. ‚ÄúThe Bushes have had their chances. It‚Äôs time for the dynasty to end.‚Äù

Bush, commissioner of the General Land Office in Texas, has faced withering criticism from both Democrats and fellow Republicans for his work restoring the Alamo historic site. He‚Äôs also been under scrutiny for his agency‚Äôs administration of veterans‚Äô homes, where the COVID fatality rate was 25 percent at seven out of nine facilities ‚Äî more than double the rate at the state‚Äôs other nursing homes during the height of the pandemic.

In his eagerness to seek endorsements from Trump, Bush has broken with members of his own family, becoming the black sheep of a clan that has little patience for Trump‚Äôs hold on the Republican Party. 

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt imagine that George P. is getting a lot of love from his family in pursuit of the Trump endorsement,‚Äù said Twombly.

Although he likely needs Trump‚Äôs endorsement to win the race, others say Bush lacks the same leadership genes that propelled his relatives to political victory.

‚ÄúWell, maybe he‚Äôs not exactly a black sheep, but Bush is not the guy,‚Äù Jerry Patterson, Bush‚Äôs predecessor on the General Land Office, told The Post. ‚ÄúI knew 41 and 43, and Bush is not a guy who is a leader. He‚Äôs a decent enough fellow, but if you want someone to make hard decisions, he‚Äôs out of it. He avoids controversy, puts his head down.‚Äù

As commissioner of the GLO, he has played fast and loose with the Alamo, the state‚Äôs most sacred historic site, he added. Patterson was so incensed with what he called Bush‚Äôs lack of transparency and bungling of the monument‚Äôs restoration that he decided to run against him to get his old job back in 2018.

When Patterson lost to Bush in the Republican primary for the commissioner‚Äôs job, he decided to back Bush‚Äôs Democratic opponent, Miguel Suazo, in the commissioner‚Äôs race. He wasn‚Äôt the only one.

‚ÄúNever in my memory have all primary opponents of a Republican candidate either endorsed the primary winner‚Äôs Democratic opponent or stated publicly they wouldn‚Äôt vote for the Republican primary winner,‚Äù Patterson said.

In addition to Patterson, losing Republican primary opponents in the race ‚Äî Rick Range, Davey Edward and David Watts ‚Äî all refused to back Bush.

‚ÄúThere are things that are more important than your party,‚Äù said Patterson, who ran the GLO between 2003 and 2015. ‚ÄúThe Alamo is Texas.‚Äù

Among the criticisms of Bush‚Äôs work on the restoration of the site, which will include a new museum with a rooftop garden, is a lack of transparency and the hiring of a Philadelphia design firm that suggested incorporating modern glass walls.

‚ÄúCalling in all these out-of-state so-called experts who knew nothing about the Alamo, nothing about what it means to Texas‚Äù was Bush‚Äôs first mistake, according to Range, a retired firefighter, in an interview with the Texas Monthly. 

‚ÄúHe cannot be trusted with the future of the Alamo,‚Äù Range told the magazine. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs flip-flopped more times than a catfish stranded on the bank of a river.‚Äù

Despite the criticisms, Bush prominently features images of the Alamo in his campaign ads, which also include several references to Trump‚Äôs domestic policy greatest hits. 

In his latest ad, Bush reminds viewers that he is a former Navy officer deployed to Afghanistan, and promises to finish ‚ÄúTrump‚Äôs wall.‚Äù He is filmed in dark glasses riding an all-terrain vehicle in the shadow of the wall that marks the southern border with Mexico. 

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs such bulls‚Äìt,‚Äù said Patterson. ‚ÄúEvery damned politician talks about the wall, but the attorney general has no impact on shutting down the border. It‚Äôs all bulls‚Äìt. It‚Äôs almost what you have to do if you are a Republican in Texas.‚Äù

Still, Patterson, like others, is hesitant to write off Bush just yet.

‚ÄúDo I think he has a chance?‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI think he has a chance.‚Äù

Bush‚Äôs campaign and spokesman did not return The Post‚Äôs calls and emails Thursday.

By Isabel Vincent
March 4, 2022 7:40am
NEW YORK POST 
 
At first glance, George Prescott Bush seems the ideal political candidate in a state where his family has been a powerful dynasty for decades.

The telegenic Texas lawyer is a grandson of 41st US President George H.W. Bush and the nephew of George W. Bush, the 43rd. He is the eldest son of two-term Florida Gov. Jeb Bush and the great-grandson of US Sen. Prescott Bush of Connecticut. The war veteran and father of two, married to blond lawyer Amanda Williams Bush, is also Mexican American on his mother‚Äôs side, and speaks fluent Spanish.

But that might not be enough, according to critics who accuse him of being the black sheep of the family and disrespecting the Alamo, Texas‚Äô most treasured symbol, by bringing in modern-minded out-of-staters for its restoration.

On Tuesday, Bush, 45, and incumbent Ken Paxton beat two other Republican candidates vying to be the party‚Äôs pick in the attorney general‚Äôs race.

Now, a critical May runoff will determine whether the fourth-generation scion will be able to shore up the family‚Äôs political legacy in the Lone Star State, analysts say. 

But that‚Äôs another problem: ‚ÄúThe Bush name is not popular in Texas anymore,‚Äù Luke Twombly, a Dallas-based political consultant and former communications director of the Texas Republican Party, told The Post.

Paxton, the Texas attorney general since 2015, has been indicted on securities fraud charges and accused of bribery and misuse of office in a civil whistleblower lawsuit, but still has the support of the state‚Äôs conservatives. He also has the endorsement of former President Donald Trump ‚Äî a situation Bush hopes to reverse by invoking Trump in his campaign ads, which don‚Äôt mention the titans in his own family.

‚ÄúUnder the leadership of President Trump, our country was strong and vibrant again,‚Äù says Bush in a campaign video. At another point in the ad, he notes, ‚ÄúLike President Trump, I will not sit idly by while our freedoms are under attack, because Texas must lead the way in fighting this radical agenda.‚Äù 

If Bush is trying to capitalize on his devotion to Trump, his opponents hope to end the Bush family‚Äôs political dominance in Texas, which began after George H.W. moved with his wife, Barbara, from Connecticut to the Lone Star State in 1948 to work in the oil business.

‚ÄúIf conservatives unite ‚Ä¶ we can end the Bush dynasty,‚Äù Paxton told a Lubbock radio station Wednesday. ‚ÄúThe Bushes have had their chances. It‚Äôs time for the dynasty to end.‚Äù

Bush, commissioner of the General Land Office in Texas, has faced withering criticism from both Democrats and fellow Republicans for his work restoring the Alamo historic site. He‚Äôs also been under scrutiny for his agency‚Äôs administration of veterans‚Äô homes, where the COVID fatality rate was 25 percent at seven out of nine facilities ‚Äî more than double the rate at the state‚Äôs other nursing homes during the height of the pandemic.

********************************************************************
 
Alamo-disrespecting George P. Bush may kill family‚Äôs political dynasty
By Isabel Vincent
March 4, 2022 7:40am
NEW YORK POST 
 
At first glance, George Prescott Bush seems the ideal political candidate in a state where his family has been a powerful dynasty for decades.

The telegenic Texas lawyer is a grandson of 41st US President George H.W. Bush and the nephew of George W. Bush, the 43rd. He is the eldest son of two-term Florida Gov. Jeb Bush and the great-grandson of US Sen. Prescott Bush of Connecticut. The war veteran and father of two, married to blond lawyer Amanda Williams Bush, is also Mexican American on his mother‚Äôs side, and speaks fluent Spanish.

But that might not be enough, according to critics who accuse him of being the black sheep of the family and disrespecting the Alamo, Texas‚Äô most treasured symbol, by bringing in modern-minded out-of-staters for its restoration.

On Tuesday, Bush, 45, and incumbent Ken Paxton beat two other Republican candidates vying to be the party‚Äôs pick in the attorney general‚Äôs race.

Now, a critical May runoff will determine whether the fourth-generation scion will be able to shore up the family‚Äôs political legacy in the Lone Star State, analysts say. 

But that‚Äôs another problem: ‚ÄúThe Bush name is not popular in Texas anymore,‚Äù Luke Twombly, a Dallas-based political consultant and former communications director of the Texas Republican Party, told The Post.

Paxton, the Texas attorney general since 2015, has been indicted on securities fraud charges and accused of bribery and misuse of office in a civil whistleblower lawsuit, but still has the support of the state‚Äôs conservatives. He also has the endorsement of former President Donald Trump ‚Äî a situation Bush hopes to reverse by invoking Trump in his campaign ads, which don‚Äôt mention the titans in his own family.

‚ÄúUnder the leadership of President Trump, our country was strong and vibrant again,‚Äù says Bush in a campaign video. At another point in the ad, he notes, ‚ÄúLike President Trump, I will not sit idly by while our freedoms are under attack, because Texas must lead the way in fighting this radical agenda.‚Äù 

If Bush is trying to capitalize on his devotion to Trump, his opponents hope to end the Bush family‚Äôs political dominance in Texas, which began after George H.W. moved with his wife, Barbara, from Connecticut to the Lone Star State in 1948 to work in the oil business.

‚ÄúIf conservatives unite ‚Ä¶ we can end the Bush dynasty,‚Äù Paxton told a Lubbock radio station Wednesday. ‚ÄúThe Bushes have had their chances. It‚Äôs time for the dynasty to end.‚Äù

Bush, commissioner of the General Land Office in Texas, has faced withering criticism from both Democrats and fellow Republicans for his work restoring the Alamo historic site. He‚Äôs also been under scrutiny for his agency‚Äôs administration of veterans‚Äô homes, where the COVID fatality rate was 25 percent at seven out of nine facilities ‚Äî more than double the rate at the state‚Äôs other nursing homes during the height of the pandemic.

In his eagerness to seek endorsements from Trump, Bush has broken with members of his own family, becoming the black sheep of a clan that has little patience for Trump‚Äôs hold on the Republican Party. 

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt imagine that George P. is getting a lot of love from his family in pursuit of the Trump endorsement,‚Äù said Twombly.

Although he likely needs Trump‚Äôs endorsement to win the race, others say Bush lacks the same leadership genes that propelled his relatives to political victory.

‚ÄúWell, maybe he‚Äôs not exactly a black sheep, but Bush is not the guy,‚Äù Jerry Patterson, Bush‚Äôs predecessor on the General Land Office, told The Post. ‚ÄúI knew 41 and 43, and Bush is not a guy who is a leader. He‚Äôs a decent enough fellow, but if you want someone to make hard decisions, he‚Äôs out of it. He avoids controversy, puts his head down.‚Äù

As commissioner of the GLO, he has played fast and loose with the Alamo, the state‚Äôs most sacred historic site, he added. Patterson was so incensed with what he called Bush‚Äôs lack of transparency and bungling of the monument‚Äôs restoration that he decided to run against him to get his old job back in 2018.

When Patterson lost to Bush in the Republican primary for the commissioner‚Äôs job, he decided to back Bush‚Äôs Democratic opponent, Miguel Suazo, in the commissioner‚Äôs race. He wasn‚Äôt the only one.

‚ÄúNever in my memory have all primary opponents of a Republican candidate either endorsed the primary winner‚Äôs Democratic opponent or stated publicly they wouldn‚Äôt vote for the Republican primary winner,‚Äù Patterson said.

In addition to Patterson, losing Republican primary opponents in the race ‚Äî Rick Range, Davey Edward and David Watts ‚Äî all refused to back Bush.

‚ÄúThere are things that are more important than your party,‚Äù said Patterson, who ran the GLO between 2003 and 2015. ‚ÄúThe Alamo is Texas.‚Äù

Among the criticisms of Bush‚Äôs work on the restoration of the site, which will include a new museum with a rooftop garden, is a lack of transparency and the hiring of a Philadelphia design firm that suggested incorporating modern glass walls.

Alamo-disrespecting George P. Bush may kill family‚Äôs political dynasty
By Isabel Vincent
March 4, 2022 7:40am
NEW YORK POST 
 
At first glance, George Prescott Bush seems the ideal political candidate in a state where his family has been a powerful dynasty for decades.

The telegenic Texas lawyer is a grandson of 41st US President George H.W. Bush and the nephew of George W. Bush, the 43rd. He is the eldest son of two-term Florida Gov. Jeb Bush and the great-grandson of US Sen. Prescott Bush of Connecticut. The war veteran and father of two, married to blond lawyer Amanda Williams Bush, is also Mexican American on his mother‚Äôs side, and speaks fluent Spanish.

But that might not be enough, according to critics who accuse him of being the black sheep of the family and disrespecting the Alamo, Texas‚Äô most treasured symbol, by bringing in modern-minded out-of-staters for its restoration.

On Tuesday, Bush, 45, and incumbent Ken Paxton beat two other Republican candidates vying to be the party‚Äôs pick in the attorney general‚Äôs race.

Now, a critical May runoff will determine whether the fourth-generation scion will be able to shore up the family‚Äôs political legacy in the Lone Star State, analysts say. 

But that‚Äôs another problem: ‚ÄúThe Bush name is not popular in Texas anymore,‚Äù Luke Twombly, a Dallas-based political consultant and former communications director of the Texas Republican Party, told The Post.

Paxton, the Texas attorney general since 2015, has been indicted on securities fraud charges and accused of bribery and misuse of office in a civil whistleblower lawsuit, but still has the support of the state‚Äôs conservatives. He also has the endorsement of former President Donald Trump ‚Äî a situation Bush hopes to reverse by invoking Trump in his campaign ads, which don‚Äôt mention the titans in his own family.

‚ÄúUnder the leadership of President Trump, our country was strong and vibrant again,‚Äù says Bush in a campaign video. At another point in the ad, he notes, ‚ÄúLike President Trump, I will not sit idly by while our freedoms are under attack, because Texas must lead the way in fighting this radical agenda.‚Äù 

If Bush is trying to capitalize on his devotion to Trump, his opponents hope to end the Bush family‚Äôs political dominance in Texas, which began after George H.W. moved with his wife, Barbara, from Connecticut to the Lone Star State in 1948 to work in the oil business.

‚ÄúIf conservatives unite ‚Ä¶ we can end the Bush dynasty,‚Äù Paxton told a Lubbock radio station Wednesday. ‚ÄúThe Bushes have had their chances. It‚Äôs time for the dynasty to end.‚Äù

Bush, commissioner of the General Land Office in Texas, has faced withering criticism from both Democrats and fellow Republicans for his work restoring the Alamo historic site. He‚Äôs also been under scrutiny for his agency‚Äôs administration of veterans‚Äô homes, where the COVID fatality rate was 25 percent at seven out of nine facilities ‚Äî more than double the rate at the state‚Äôs other nursing homes during the height of the pandemic.

In his eagerness to seek endorsements from Trump, Bush has broken with members of his own family, becoming the black sheep of a clan that has little patience for Trump‚Äôs hold on the Republican Party. 

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt imagine that George P. is getting a lot of love from his family in pursuit of the Trump endorsement,‚Äù said Twombly.

Although he likely needs Trump‚Äôs endorsement to win the race, others say Bush lacks the same leadership genes that propelled his relatives to political victory.

‚ÄúWell, maybe he‚Äôs not exactly a black sheep, but Bush is not the guy,‚Äù Jerry Patterson, Bush‚Äôs predecessor on the General Land Office, told The Post. ‚ÄúI knew 41 and 43, and Bush is not a guy who is a leader. He‚Äôs a decent enough fellow, but if you want someone to make hard decisions, he‚Äôs out of it. He avoids controversy, puts his head down.‚Äù

As commissioner of the GLO, he has played fast and loose with the Alamo, the state‚Äôs most sacred historic site, he added. Patterson was so incensed with what he called Bush‚Äôs lack of transparency and bungling of the monument‚Äôs restoration that he decided to run against him to get his old job back in 2018.

When Patterson lost to Bush in the Republican primary for the commissioner‚Äôs job, he decided to back Bush‚Äôs Democratic opponent, Miguel Suazo, in the commissioner‚Äôs race. He wasn‚Äôt the only one.

‚ÄúNever in my memory have all primary opponents of a Republican candidate either endorsed the primary winner‚Äôs Democratic opponent or stated publicly they wouldn‚Äôt vote for the Republican primary winner,‚Äù Patterson said.

In addition to Patterson, losing Republican primary opponents in the race ‚Äî Rick Range, Davey Edward and David Watts ‚Äî all refused to back Bush.

‚ÄúThere are things that are more important than your party,‚Äù said Patterson, who ran the GLO between 2003 and 2015. ‚ÄúThe Alamo is Texas.‚Äù

Among the criticisms of Bush‚Äôs work on the restoration of the site, which will include a new museum with a rooftop garden, is a lack of transparency and the hiring of a Philadelphia design firm that suggested incorporating modern glass walls.

‚ÄúCalling in all these out-of-state so-called experts who knew nothing about the Alamo, nothing about what it means to Texas‚Äù was Bush‚Äôs first mistake, according to Range, a retired firefighter, in an interview with the Texas Monthly. 

‚ÄúHe cannot be trusted with the future of the Alamo,‚Äù Range told the magazine. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs flip-flopped more times than a catfish stranded on the bank of a river.‚Äù
